utterances: Bob Mondello is our man on film and on the Bond beat.
This past week three different architectural firms unveiled their plans for new office towers on the site of the World Trade Center.
Architect Hugh Hardy has done work at the site and on the eve of the 9/11 anniversary we close our program with his thoughts.
The twin towers of the World Trade Center gave New York a landmark whose severe profile was impudently tall.
Often ridiculed as lacking grace, the towers gave the city's downtown a distinctive silhouette.
Its loss has diminished contrast among building types, making the skyline more homogenous and less bold.
The top of Tower One once held Windows On The World on floors 106 and 107.
It was the highest restaurant in the world, offering dining more than 100 stories in the air, and it became a dramatic part of big city lore.
In 1996 we expanded and redesigned those floors to enhance this international destination.
Its panoramic views offered an unparallel way to experience New York and gave cache to an otherwise bland complex of buildings.
Now, after five years of planning and design proposals, are we any closer to constructing a similar experience for this part of the city?
Although the site lies in the heart of New York's historic business district, it's planning is controlled by the state, not the city.
The renewal of its six acres requires an elaborate interplay of governmental and political institutions.
It also requires a clarity of purpose and the political muscle to create consensus.
Both have been visibly absent.

Planning for the site represents a great struggle between those who appropriately envision a vast memorial, a sacred place of remembrance, and those who view it as a place for the area's rebirth as an active mixed-use urban center of residential neighborhoods and businesses like Windows On The World.
These people believe new life on this site would be the best response to terrorism.
Imagine my excitement at the opportunity to return to this site and to design the 40th floor of Seven World Trade Center, the first high rise construction there since 9/11.
This month it becomes the new home of the New York Academy of Sciences.
The building is an elegant parallelogram clad with shimmering glass walls, a handsome response to devastation and a measure of the market for new office in downtown.
Skidmore, Owings and Merrill's design for this simple building securely suggests that architecture need not writhe about to achieve distinction.
Carl, nice work.

Well, there's something that runs afoul of the comfort side of comfort cooking when you bring in this sort of hipster-influenced individual gadget-related cooking, where suddenly everything has 54 ingredients and it's Stumptown this and artisanally hand-folded that.
(Laughter).
It's very funny, and we pole a lot of fun at hipster expense.
But I think there really is something to - if you make artisanal cake pops at home because you tried them in a new bakery...
As opposed to cake.
Exactly.
That's what I was going to say.
When you make cake, we have to get plates out, and we have a shared experience all together around the table.
But when you hand out cake pops, everyone can disappear back to their corner and tap away at their screens by themselves.
(Laughter) Now, you just spent Thanksgiving with your relatives, right?
That's correct.
That's right.
So you didn't do the cooking.
I wonder, did you inspect the kitchen for hipster gizmos that might have crept into the making of your meal?
I did, indeed, to make sure that it wasn't polluted by such gadgetry.
And the only thing I found that was sort of interesting - 'cause I had never considered it this way before - but the turkey baster itself is kind of an individual gizmo, if you will.
Right?
We don't call it a meat baster.
It's really just for this one single purpose.
But yeah, they're very traditional cooks.
And - I didn't see any evidence of creeping hipster-ism (ph) there.
Kitchen - but, you know, kitchen gadgets are popular holiday gifts.
Now, I try not to buy one, as you say, if it only does one thing.
But did you find any gizmos that you particularly don't want to receive?

I don't want to receive a mini donut maker or a waffle stick maker or a cronut maker or any of these kind of gadgets that only have this one purpose because now I'm in for storing and maintaining a new item that I'll probably use twice the first month and once in the three-month period after that and then let go forever.
One gadget that exemplifies exactly what I don't want for Christmas, even as a stocking stuffer, is the dedicated three-prong sausage pricker.
I don't think I (laughter) understand what that is.
Well, you know, when you're grilling sausages, they can burst unappealingly or unattractively, let's say, on the grill if you don't prick them first.
But we already have a dedicated three-pronged sausage pricker.
It sits to the left of every plate in America.
So I'm not sure why I'd need a separate...
Called a fork (laughter).
That's right, exactly (laughter).
Keith Blanchard wrote an article for The Wall Street Journal which is called ""Why Hipster Cooking Gizmos Are Killing Cooking.
Keith, thank you.
Thank you very much, Linda.
It was nice to be here.
Walk around the campus of the University of Southern Indiana, and you may notice a very small house.
It's part of an experiment to create houses of 600 square feet that can be built in days.
These little homes could offer housing alternatives for elderly people.
Isaiah Seibert of member station WNIN in Evansville has the story.
The small, 600-square-foot modular house is called Minka.
The name is derived from a simple and functional style of Japanese home.

Bill Thomas is a geriatrician by training, but today he's overseeing the construction of one of the first Minka prototypes on this university campus in southwestern Indiana, with his elderly patients in mind.
This is the Minka revolution.
(SOUNDBITE OF HAMMERING)
Workers hammer away, putting the final touches on the foundation.
No one will live in this prototype house.
It's being built for research.
But housing officials from Loveland, Colo., a town about 50 miles north of Denver, have different plans for Minka houses.
I'm really interested in observing the actual construction method because it is different than what we are used to.
Darcy McClure is director of real estate development with the Loveland Housing Authority.
Its projects are normally stick-built with everything constructed on site.
But Minka houses are modular.
Parts of the house, like floor boxes and wall panels, are built in a factory and shipped to the site.
As for construction, think Legos.
Next summer, Loveland will break ground on its own Minka houses.
They're initially building nine to house senior citizens.
The fact they want to do this type of housing in community build is awesome.
It's brilliant - because that's the need that's out there right now.
Valerie Jurik-Henry is a North Carolina-based housing consultant who works with builders to construct accessible homes and is a big fan of modular houses.
While the idea of modular homes for the elderly isn't unique, it's use for a whole community is intriguing.
Each house costs about $75,000 to build, and they're constructed quickly - very quickly.
While stick-build homes can take months to construct, you can build a Minka house in just a few days.
Jurik-Henry thinks this project can help raise awareness about alternatives to the single-family home.
She notes a severe lack of knowledge about housing options in this country.
People often choose houses for themselves based on what they've grown up in.
But what people know and what people actually need can be very different, and that's part of the idea behind a Minka house.

If you have a small, high-tech, compact, livable house and you have good neighbors close by, you can maintain your independence for a lot longer than if you're living alone in a house at the end of a cul-de-sac.

There were significant pushback votes in the Senate this week on Saudi Arabia policy and on a judicial nomination and on a bill to protect Robert Mueller and his investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election.
But did the Senate do anything about Robert Mueller?
And some other news this morning.
A rocket from Gaza has struck a home in central Israel this morning wounding at least seven Israelis.
This is raising the prospect of more violence just two weeks before Israel holds elections.
NPR's Daniel Estrin reports from Jerusalem.
Yeah.
Now, as the new health care law was rolling out, we heard a lot about the troubles with the healthcare.gov website.
A handful of states also set up their own online health insurance marketplaces with varying degrees of success.
Connecticut, for its part, is happy with the results.
They actually think other states might learn from their experience.
Jeff Cohen from WNPR in Hartford reports.
Kevin Counihan is walking through the 15th floor of this downtown Hartford office building, past the legal department, the IT folks and the consultants.
He stops in front of three wall-mounted computer screens.
You're looking at the number of concurrent users on the site.
So you can see that there are 212 people in the process of applying for insurance on the site.
The site is AccessHealthCT.com.
It's Connecticut's portal for its state-run exchange under Obamacare, and Counihan is the CEO.
Now, this screen gives, in real time, our enrollment and call center metrics.
And he says those monitors, metrics and technology are all just a part of what his agency is doing well.
Connecticut is widely seen as one of those states that's succeeding with Obamacare.
For one, its website works.
More importantly, it's already exceeded its first-year enrollment goals, and other states have noticed.
We were approached by several states who said: Would you have any interest in franchising your exchange, your IT platform, your key functionality to us, as a state?
As we thought about that, we began coming up with this concept of an exchange in a box.
Think of it as Obamacare a la carte.
Need a better executive team?
Let Counihan's people run your show, for a fee.
Need help managing your vendors?
They can do that, too.
His technology infrastructure is scalable, he says, which is computer-speak for don't rebuild your own website.
Let us do it.
And you can have your own state-specific look and feel, too.
Sales, marketing, legal: Why do it yourself when Connecticut can do it for you?
